sn47.38:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn47.38:1.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.38:1.4: As they do so they completely understand the body.
sn47.38:1.5: When the body is completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:2.1: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.38:2.2: As they do so they completely understand feelings.
sn47.38:2.3: When feelings are completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:3.1: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.38:3.2: As they do so they completely understand the mind.
sn47.38:3.3: When the mind is completely understood they realize the deathless.
sn47.38:4.1: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
sn47.38:4.2: As they do so they completely understand principles.
sn47.38:4.3: When principles are completely understood they realize the deathless.”
